channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Defying U.S., Afghanistan to Free Prisoners Accused of Killing Americans
item.description: Intensifying his showdown with Washington, President Hamid Karzai ordered the release of 72 detainees, citing insufficient evidence.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Tunisia’s Islamist Leader Resigns, Formally Ending His Party’s Rule
item.description: Ali Larayedh’s resignation was part of a carefully calibrated plan to end months of gridlock and prepare for new elections in the birthplace of the Arab Spring.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Prime Minister Ali Larayedh of Tunisia submitted his resignation on Thursday.

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills 22 Recruits in Iraq
item.description: The attacker infiltrated a line of men signing up to fight with government forces in Anbar Province.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Discovery of Bombs and Corpses Rattles Already Tense Caucasus Region
item.description: Improvised explosive devices and the bodies of six men who had been shot were found in the Stavropol area, stirring new worries about terrorism.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: E.C.B. Holds Rates at Record Low but Is Ready to Consider Further Steps
item.description: The European Central Bank’s president said he would “consider all available instruments” if the threat of deflation persists.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: E.U. Panel Invites Snowden to Testify on Privacy Breaches
item.description: A parliamentary committee asked Edward J. Snowden to speak via video about protecting citizens’ privacy.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras/The Guardian, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The testimony would be done by video so Edward Snowden would not have to leave Russia.

item.title: As Nuclear Talks Resume in Geneva, Iran’s Top Leader Castigates U.S.
item.description: The remarks by Ayatollah Khamenei may have been designed to strengthen Iran’s position at the negotiations.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Pakistan Blast Kills Senior Police Officer
item.description: Muhammad Aslam Khan, a police investigator involved in operations against the Pakistani Taliban, was killed in Karachi along with two others.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 9
item.description: Snow-capped rooftops in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Germany to Help in Disposal of Syrian Chemical Weapons
item.description: The decision was in part to maintain international credibility in addressing Syria’s civil war, the foreign minister says.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: A training grenade was dismantled during a demonstration at a chemical weapons disposal facility near Münster in October.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Police Find Dead Tiger in S.U.V. in Wenzhou
item.description: The police report said the authorities suspected the carcass to be of a Siberian, or Amur, tiger, one of the world’s most endangered animals, and had sent samples to be tested.
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: The police were surprised when they unwrapped the bound tarpaulin the men had been carrying.

item.title: French Court Says Fugitive Kazakh Banker Can Be Extradited
item.description: Mukhtar Ablyazov has been accused of embezzling as much as $6 billion from the bank he once controlled. His lawyer says the charges are political.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Tunisia's Islamist Prime Minister Resigns
item.description: Tunisia's Islamist prime minister announced his resignation Thursday in favor of a caretaker government that will supervise new elections later this year and complete the North African country's long delayed transition to democracy.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: India Ink: Legal Experts Weigh in on Citizen Sting Operations
item.description: Delhi residents are enthusiastic about a new initiative to help them catch corrupt government officials, but lawyers have mixed opinions.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE and VISHNU VARMA

item.title: India Ink: Flashing Red Symbols of Privilege Likely to be Tough to Turn Off
item.description: The Delhi chief minister’s efforts to get rid of the red beacon used by government officials are likely to run into opposition from those used to using the lights to cut through traffic.
item.dc:creator: By SAI MANISH

item.title: Britain Keeps Interest Rates Unchanged Amid Signs of Recovery
item.description: The Bank of England said it would hold its benchmark rate at a record low 0.5 percent as headwinds continue to check the recent economic uptick.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA WERDIGIER

item.title: Letter From Europe: 100 Years After the Great War, the Bad Guy Is Still Elusive
item.description: Blaming German expansionism is simplistic in today's debate, in which historians think the war's roots were far more tangled.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Chinese Film Director Fined for Exceeding Child Limits
item.description: The director, Zhang Yimou, and his wife were ordered to pay $1.24 million as a penalty for having three children.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Zhang Yimou in New York City in 2011.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Latest China-Japan Spat: Who’s Voldemort?
item.description: In their latest round of name-calling, China and Japan invoke the villain of children’s fiction also known as He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Adding Sex to the Chinese Dream
item.description: In a place where sex is still substantially mired in shame, some Chinese are trying to bring about a fundamental change in the way their culture views pleasure.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ma Jiajia, who owns several sex shops in Beijing, has her own take on the Chinese Dream.

item.title: North Korea Rejects South’s Bid for Family Reunions
item.description: The reunions would be a way to improve tense ties between North and South Korea, allowing meetings of relatives who have been split for decades.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Smoking Prevalence Steady in China, but Numbers Rise
item.description: Because of population growth, China added nearly 100 million new smokers between 1980 and 2012, though the rate of smoking in recent years has remained fairly stable, according to a new global study on the habit.
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: Men represent the overwhelming majority of smokers in China, even more so than in 1980.

item.title: Rodman Apologizes for Remarks on American Jailed in North Korea
item.description: The former basketball star said he had been drinking when he suggested that Kenneth Bae, sentenced in May to 15 years of hard labor, deserved his fate.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: C. T. Hsia, Scholar of Chinese Literature, Dies at 92
item.description: Dr. Hsia helped introduce modern Chinese literature to the West in the 1960s while teaching at Columbia University.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY

item.title: Senator Signals Support for Sending Helicopters to Iraq
item.description: Bob Menendez, a powerful Senate Democrat, indicated that he might allow the transfer of AH-64 Apache helicopters to Iraq as Baghdad struggles to recapture key territory from Islamic extremists.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ERIC SCHMITT
